content.body: I agree that it would be nice to make some basic usages more prominent in the readme
content.formatted_body: I agree that it would be nice to make some basic usages more prominent in the readme

content.body: Basically if the readme could be more like the first half of the previous presentation pasted together with the presentation from next meeting
content.formatted_body: Basically if the readme could be more like the first half of the previous presentation pasted together with the presentation from next meeting

content.body: RE https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context/issues/52, I'm now thinking if GC times may not be good enough for my immediate use case
and potentially something we can more tightly define once it's actually required
Garbage collection is not an option here IMO
I agree it's not an option for timestamps
as GC can be arbitrarily late
but it can be an option (I think) for TaskAttribution's container management

I think we have to deal with GC in a few cases:
1. `AsyncContext.wrap()`
2. `new Promise(() => {})` (permanently pending promise)
content.formatted_body:
I think we have to deal with GC in a few cases:

  1. AsyncContext.wrap()
  2. new Promise(() => {}) (permanently pending promise)

content.body: There's an optimistic fast path for promises that resolve (we can decrement the pending counter as soon as that happens), but promises aren't guaranteed to resolve ever.
